turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Chenjiamman.
turn.1: What happened in the year 810 AD with Chenjiamman?
turn.2: From the Coleroon to Tirupati, emoluments were made to that Amman.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: A descendant of those trustees, Appacāmi Piḷḷai, is an important pūcāri ["periya pūcāri"] down to today.
turn.6: The historian van den Hoek notes Draupadi as the goddess of Gingee's northern boundary and Cellattāmmaṉ as the goddess of Madurai's northern boundary are linked to Mahishasuramarshini, the slayer of Mahishasura; with Cellattamman also being a recipient of buffalo sacrifice on the 8th day of her 10-day festival, with the priest for the sacrifice supplied by the Madurai Meenakshi Amman Temple.
turn.8: The Cellattāmmaṉ myth states when Ishvara and Ishvari (Shiva and his spouse) were walking through a forest, Ishvari became thirsty, killed a buffalo and drank its blood.
turn.10: When Isvara found her decorated with the animal's entrails, he no longer wanted her in his vicinity, but left her with the power to guard the northern boundary with her fierce character.
turn.12: Draupadi and Cellattāmmaṉ are both virgins in the legends.
